data.text: @shallowbrigade (Apologies if you knew that, I’ve been teaching all day and it’s hard to stop :)
@shallowbrigade He’s saying that, if you roll the die over and over again, you will hit eventually either way. He is neglecting that the expected waiting time is different in the two case, though.

@shallowbrigade One last thing - I get the sense this is intentionally confusing to obscure leaps from being vaccinated to masking sans vaccination to masking as protection when others aren't masked to the exaggerated dice roll metaphor to argue masking doesn't make a difference

@shallowbrigade Even if his confusing & admittedly exaggerated analogy was how it works, there's still a huge between 1 in 6 and 2 in 6. 
An estimated 65% of people are fully vaccinated & 76% have one dose. That's around 83 to 115 million people at high risk. How does normal flow from that?

@cmautner In context he's trying to explain risk for the a masks unvaccinated person encountering someone infected & unmasked, but it's barely coherent & one could just say "so high it's near inevitable". Not why he cites this as a lead up to arguing for continuing to remove restrictions.

@shallowbrigade It also assumes one is encountering an unmasked infected person, a valid assumption to make but one that should be mentioned.
His conclusion this means "there is a strong argument for continuing to remove other restrictions, and returning to normal life" seems a BS reach at best

@shallowbrigade He could have just written "Omnicron is so infectious that masking without vaccination is are unlikely to prevent infection, just slightly reduce the risk. So repeat exposures without vaccines make infection almost inevitable." and leave it at that.
@shallowbrigade I read that too and had no idea what he was talking about

@shallowbrigade I mean, this is who he is. He was a  nothing moderate lib default and then he decided to be the voice of centrist covid denialism and became a superstar. These newsletter columns about how we should all tear our masks off are his bread and butter.
